headline.main: A Stylist Launches a New Line of Denim

docs.slideshow_credits: Stevie Dance for The Feel Studio Inc.​

docs.abstract: The journalist on mass shootings, not believing in prisons and if Donald Trump has gotten in his 10,000 hours of practice for presidential greatness.
docs.snippet: The journalist on mass shootings, not believing in prisons and if Donald Trump has gotten in his 10,000 hours of practice for presidential greatness.
docs.lead_paragraph: You just started Season 3 of your podcast, “Revisionist History,” which explores, as you put it, “the overlooked and the misunderstood.” What’s the most widely misunderstood event in history? Oh, my God. I have no idea. If I knew that, I’d do an episode on it. I think that the premise of the show is that everything is misunderstood in some way, and that there is great virtue in coming to a subject late. In a media culture that is so obsessed with being first, I would like to be last.

headline.main: Malcolm Gladwell Likes Things Better in Canada
headline.print_headline: Malcolm Gladwell Likes Things Better In Canada

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on visiting friends and family with pain-relieving drugs in tow, and on how to deal with an aging friend’s dementia.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on visiting friends and family with pain-relieving drugs in tow, and on how to deal with an aging friend’s dementia.
docs.lead_paragraph: I have developed a non-life-threatening medical condition that is incurable and has only limited conventional therapy. Symptoms appear at night with torturous pain. The physician-prescribed remedies are not working well. After reviewing online articles and discussion with one physician, I decided to try medical marijuana, which I take in pill form before bed. It has been marginally successful in providing some relief and allowing me to sleep. This is legal in my state, and I have gone through appropriate channels to purchase tablets at an approved dispensary.

headline.main: Should I Tell My Hosts About My Medical Marijuana?
headline.print_headline: Should I Tell My Hosts About My Medical Marijuana?

docs.abstract: Does the man of the house have a say?
docs.snippet: Does the man of the house have a say?
docs.lead_paragraph: Max writes: I would like you to order my 14-year-old daughter, Baby, to get rid of her fart corner: the corner in her bedroom she goes to whenever she needs to fart. I find it disgusting, but more important, it’s right where our cat, Hobbes, likes to sit.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Dedicating a Space to Flatulence
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Change the image you use to describe reality, and reality might change along with it.
docs.snippet: Change the image you use to describe reality, and reality might change along with it.
docs.lead_paragraph: — From Christine Schutt’s “Pure Hollywood: And Other Stories” (Grove Press, 2018, Page 96). Schutt is the author of two previous collections and three novels, including the National Book Award finalist “Florida.”

headline.main: New Sentences: From Christine Schutt’s ‘Pure Hollywood’

docs.abstract: The geophysicist on climate-change deniers, optimism for the planet and women in STEM fields.
docs.snippet: The geophysicist on climate-change deniers, optimism for the planet and women in STEM fields.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, you began your tenure as the president-elect of the American Geophysical Union, a global organization of earth and space scientists who work on ensuring a sustainable future. Do you feel as if we’re at a crossroads for climate change? Yes. We’ve gone from a place where scientists predicted change from invisible gases, to where we could visibly see the change in the polar region, to now seeing it on our front doorsteps from warmer days, shorter winters and rising sea levels. Our knowledge of our planet has made science political, but it’s not — it’s a public resource.

headline.main: Robin Bell Doesn’t Think Science Should Be Political
headline.print_headline: Robin Bell Doesn’t Think Science Should Be Political

docs.abstract: Knowing what’s going to happen can amplify the pleasure of the moviegoing experience.
docs.snippet: Knowing what’s going to happen can amplify the pleasure of the moviegoing experience.
docs.lead_paragraph: One fateful summer evening, I hurried home from work, eager to catch up on “Game of Thrones.” I don’t have cable, so I often watch my shows a day or two after they air, usually via some streaming service or an app. At the time, I had become an obsessive avoider of spoilers, the kind of person who stayed off Instagram and Twitter during live episodes of popular shows, even going so far as to turn off notifications to avoid reading about a reveal or twist that would ruin a surprise.

docs.abstract: The scandal revealed just how much we’d come to trust Facebook — and clarified what the company is really capable of.
docs.snippet: The scandal revealed just how much we’d come to trust Facebook — and clarified what the company is really capable of.
docs.lead_paragraph: The queasy truth at the heart of Facebook’s Cambridge Analytica scandal, which is so far the company’s defining disgrace of 2018, is that its genesis became scandalous only in retrospect. The series of events that now implicate Facebook began in 2014, in plain view, with a listing on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk service, where users can complete small tasks for commensurately modest sums of cash. In exchange for installing a Facebook app and completing a survey — in the process granting the app access to parts of your Facebook profile — you would get around a dollar. Maybe two.

headline.main: Cambridge Analytica and the Coming Data Bust
headline.print_headline: Cambridge Analytica and the Coming Data Bust

docs.abstract: Doctors can get so focused on explanation that they lose sight of the importance of description.
docs.snippet: Doctors can get so focused on explanation that they lose sight of the importance of description.
docs.lead_paragraph: Late one evening in the medical library of the hospital where I work, I opened The Lancet, the medical journal, and came across a case report written by the neurologist-writer Oliver Sacks and colleagues. “In July 2011, a 52-year-old woman presented to our psychiatric outpatient clinic in The Hague with a lifelong history of seeing people’s faces change into dragonlike faces.”

headline.main: What Can Odd, Interesting Medical Case Studies Teach Us?
headline.print_headline: What doctors have lost by neglecting idiosyncratic, individual case studies.

docs.abstract: We rigorously research the medicine molecules we put in our bodies. We should be doing the same for the nutrients we ingest.
docs.snippet: We rigorously research the medicine molecules we put in our bodies. We should be doing the same for the nutrients we ingest.
docs.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I had a minor surgical procedure — the repair of a congenital abdominal hernia. The operation went well. I returned home with a stash of instructions and medicines. There were clear guidelines for which drugs to take for inflammation or pain, in what dose, and in what order and intervals.

headline.main: It’s Time to Study Whether Eating Particular Diets Can Help Heal Us
headline.print_headline: It’s Time to Study Whether Eating Particular Diets Can Help Heal Us
